<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 176, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 904, 292]]<|/det|>
0625/62  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 325, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Alternative to Practical  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 301, 904, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2025  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[853, 326, 904, 340]]<|/det|>
1 hour  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 399]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 434, 805, 558]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 212, 601]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 603, 88]]<|/det|>
A student determines the internal diameter \(d\) of a test-tube.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 104, 530, 120]]<|/det|>
The apparatus is assembled as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[306, 144, 695, 355]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 384, 532, 401]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 1.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 418, 148, 435]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 418, 262, 434]]<|/det|>
The student:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 448, 684, 464]]<|/det|>
• fills a measuring cylinder with water up to the \(100 \text{cm}^3\) mark

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 464, 725, 479]]<|/det|>
• pours some water from the measuring cylinder into the test-tube.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 494, 180, 511]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 494, 796, 510]]<|/det|>
A full-size diagram of the bottom part of the test-tube is shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[270, 524, 725, 700]]<|/det|>
<center>Fig. 1.2</center>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 751, 801, 767]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 1.2, measure the height \(h\) in centimetres to the nearest millimetre.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 782, 657, 798]]<|/det|>
Record your result in the top row of Table 1.1 on page 4.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 782, 920, 798]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 72, 178, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[190, 72, 785, 90]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.3 shows the volume of water remaining in the measuring cylinder.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[327, 103, 673, 287]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 308, 533, 325]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 1.3

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 339, 840, 357]]<|/det|>
Take the reading \(R\) of the volume of water remaining in the measuring cylinder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 370, 570, 387]]<|/det|>
Record your result in the top row of Table 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 370, 918, 388]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 401, 180, 419]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 401, 668, 418]]<|/det|>
Calculate the volume \(V\) of water poured into the test-tube.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 432, 343, 448]]<|/det|>
Use the equation:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 462, 576, 480]]<|/det|>
\[V = (100\mathrm{cm}^3 -R).\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 494, 453, 510]]<|/det|>
Record your result in Table 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 494, 918, 511]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[55, 30, 413, 67]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 72, 536, 87]]<|/det|> 
Table 1.1

<|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[181, 104, 817, 308]]<|/det|>

\(h/\text {cm}\)\(R/\text {cm}^{3}\)\(V/\text {cm}^{3}\)
5.08416
7.67525
10.36436
13.65347


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 322, 148, 339]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 322, 264, 339]]<|/det|>
The student:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 354, 712, 370]]<|/det|>
• adds more water from the measuring cylinder into the test-tube

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 370, 640, 386]]<|/det|>
• measures the new height \(h\) of the water in the test-tube

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 386, 834, 401]]<|/det|>
• measures the new reading \(R\) of the water remaining in the measuring cylinder

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 401, 592, 416]]<|/det|>
• calculates the volume of water \(V\) in the test-tube

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 416, 677, 432]]<|/det|>
• repeats the procedure for three more values of \(h\) , \(R\) and \(V\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 447, 525, 463]]<|/det|>
The student's results are shown in Table 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 477, 917, 508]]<|/det|>
It is important to avoid line-of-sight (parallax) errors when reading the scale of the measuring cylinder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 523, 690, 539]]<|/det|>
Describe how such errors are avoided. You may draw a diagram.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 750, 920, 766]]<|/det|>
[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 873, 90]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(V / \text{cm}^3\) (\(y\)-axis) against \(h / \text{cm}\) (\(x\)-axis). Start your axes at the origin (0, 0).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 101, 400, 117]]<|/det|>
Draw the best-fit straight line.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 128, 895, 555]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 564, 920, 581]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 594, 149, 613]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 594, 918, 628]]<|/det|>
Determine the gradient \(G\) of your line. Show all working and indicate on the graph the values you use.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 675, 917, 693]]<|/det|>
<form>G = ........................................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 708, 148, 727]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 708, 180, 727]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 708, 918, 725]]<|/det|>
The internal diameter \(d\) of a cylinder is given by the equation \(d = k\sqrt{G}\) , where \(k = 1.13 \text{cm}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 739, 430, 757]]<|/det|>
Calculate \(d\) for the test-tube.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 806, 917, 823]]<|/det|>
<form>d = ............................................................... cm [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 838, 181, 857]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 838, 795, 855]]<|/det|>
Suggest one reason why your calculated value for \(d\) is only approximate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 901, 920, 919]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[826, 930, 920, 945]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[824, 945, 920, 960]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 576, 90]]<|/det|>
A student investigates a light-dependent resistor (LDR).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 104, 918, 136]]<|/det|>
The student assembles a series circuit consisting of a power supply, a switch, a \(470\Omega\) resistor and an LDR.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 151, 146, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 151, 652, 168]]<|/det|>
Fig. 2.1 shows part of the circuit that the student assembles.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[307, 210, 688, 320]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[200, 420, 920, 544]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 510, 800, 555]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 580, 533, 597]]<|/det|>
<mark>Fig. 2.2**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 612, 920, 630]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 644, 148, 662]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 644, 180, 662]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[190, 644, 301, 661]]<|/det|>
The student:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 675, 377, 691]]<|/det|>
• closes the switch

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 692, 616, 707]]<|/det|>
• connects a voltmeter across the \(470\Omega\) resistor

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 707, 536, 722]]<|/det|>
• records the reading on the voltmeter

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 723, 378, 737]]<|/det|>
• opens the switch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 752, 920, 783]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 2.1, draw a voltmeter connected to measure the potential difference (p.d.) across the \(470\Omega\) resistor. [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 72, 176, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 72, 546, 90]]<|/det|>
The voltmeter reading is shown in Fig. 2.3.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[300, 102, 687, 265]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 279, 533, 297]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 2.3

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 310, 490, 329]]<|/det|>
Record the voltmeter reading \(V_{XY}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[534, 341, 918, 359]]<|/det|>
<form>V_{XY} = ............................................................ V [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 373, 146, 392]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 373, 640, 390]]<|/det|>
The current \(I\) in the circuit is calculated using the equation:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 394, 536, 425]]<|/det|>
\[I = \frac{V_{XY}}{R},\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 432, 302, 450]]<|/det|>
where \(R = 470\Omega .\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 463, 662, 481]]<|/det|>
Use your voltmeter reading in (b)(ii) to calculate the current \(I\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[556, 578, 918, 597]]<|/det|>
<form>I = .................................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 611, 148, 630]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 611, 263, 630]]<|/det|>
The student:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 643, 339, 658]]<|/det|>
• closes the switch

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 658, 584, 674]]<|/det|>
• connects the voltmeter between points Y and Z

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 674, 475, 690]]<|/det|>
• records the voltmeter reading \(V_{YZ}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 691, 341, 705]]<|/det|>
• opens the switch.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[534, 720, 770, 744]]<|/det|>
\[V_{YZ} = \text{................................................} 2.2 \text{V}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 755, 750, 772]]<|/det|>
Calculate the resistance \(R_{\mathrm{B}}\) of the LDR in bright light using the equation:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[452, 776, 546, 808]]<|/det|>
\[R_{\mathrm{B}} = \frac{V_{\mathrm{YZ}}}{I}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[542, 903, 920, 921]]<|/det|>
<form>R_{\mathrm{B}} = ............................................................ $\Omega$ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 180, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 918, 106]]<|/det|> The student covers the LDR with a piece of card and repeats the procedure described in (b) and (d). <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[530, 119, 917, 140]]<|/det|> \[V_{XY} = \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \quad 0.15V\] <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[530, 155, 917, 176]]<|/det|> \[V_{YZ} = \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \quad 2.9V\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 189, 771, 207]]<|/det|> Calculate the resistance \(R_{\mathrm{D}}\) of the LDR in the dark using the equation: <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[421, 210, 578, 246]]<|/det|> \[R_{\mathrm{D}} = \frac{470\Omega\times V_{\mathrm{YZ}}}{V_{\mathrm{XY}}}.\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 338, 917, 356]]<|/det|>
R_{\mathrm{D}} = \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \quad \Omega \quad [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 368, 180, 386]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 368, 918, 416]]<|/det|> The student removes the card from the top of the LDR and slowly lifts it vertically upwards away from the LDR until the card is \(30 \text{cm}\) above the LDR. The student observes and records the readings on the voltmeter across the LDR \((V_{\text{YZ}})\) as the card is raised. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 431, 504, 447]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 shows the student's results. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[240, 494, 757, 712]]<|/det|>
distance/cmpotential difference \(V_{\text{YZ}}/V\)
02.9
52.5
102.4
152.3
202.2
252.2
302.2
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 724, 918, 757]]<|/det|> Describe how the p.d. across the LDR \((V_{\text{YZ}})\) changes as the distance between the card and the LDR increases. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 833, 918, 850]]<|/det|> [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 144, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 750, 90]]<|/det|>
When the LDR is covered by the card, the current in the circuit changes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 103, 918, 136]]<|/det|>
Use the student's results from **(b)(ii)**, **(d)** and **(e)(i)** to show how this change in current affects the value of the total potential difference \((V_{XY} + V_{YZ})\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[834, 242, 918, 260]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 72, 95, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 72, 630, 88]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the image formed by a converging lens.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 103, 260, 119]]<|/det|>
Refer to Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 134, 148, 151]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 134, 262, 150]]<|/det|>
The student:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 165, 372, 180]]<|/det|>
• switches on the lamp

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 182, 917, 212]]<|/det|>
• places the screen a distance \(D = 80.0 \text{cm}\) from the illuminated object (a triangular hole in a piece of card)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 212, 571, 227]]<|/det|>
• places the lens close to the illuminated object

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 228, 917, 259]]<|/det|>
moves the lens away from the illuminated object until a magnified, inverted, sharp image of the illuminated object is formed on the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 274, 680, 290]]<|/det|>
Fig. 3.1 shows the position of the lens when the image is sharp.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[75, 304, 922, 483]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 503, 534, 520]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 3.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 535, 181, 552]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 535, 917, 566]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 3.1, measure, to the nearest 0.1 cm, the object distance \(x\) from the centre of the lens to the illuminated object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 580, 917, 596]]<|/det|>
<form>x = ............................................................ cm [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 612, 181, 630]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 612, 583, 628]]<|/det|>
Fig. 3.1 is drawn to a scale of one-fifth full size.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 644, 520, 660]]<|/det|>
Calculate the actual object distance \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 704, 917, 720]]<|/det|>
<form>X = ............................................................ cm [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 736, 149, 753]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 736, 262, 752]]<|/det|>
The student:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 766, 917, 797]]<|/det|>
• continues to move the lens away from the illuminated object until a second sharp image, which is diminished and inverted, is formed on the screen

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 798, 917, 828]]<|/det|>
• measures, to the nearest 0.1 cm, the object distance \(Y\) from the centre of the lens to the illuminated object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 844, 759, 861]]<|/det|>
<form>Y = ................................................. 59.8 cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 181, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 500, 90]]<|/det|>
Fig. 3.2 shows the illuminated object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 103, 766, 121]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 3.2, draw a diminished, inverted image in the space provided.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 165, 375, 310]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[677, 298, 732, 316]]<|/det|>
<form>image</form>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 333, 534, 352]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 351, 920, 370]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 383, 181, 401]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 383, 455, 400]]<|/det|>
Calculate the value \(d = (Y - X)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 443, 900, 460]]<|/det|>
<form>d = ............................................................ $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 444, 920, 462]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 475, 146, 494]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 475, 667, 492]]<|/det|>
The focal length \(f\) of the lens can be found using the equation:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 496, 557, 527]]<|/det|>
\[f = \frac{(D^2 - d^2)}{4D}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 535, 918, 568]]<|/det|>
Use the value of \(D\) from **(a)** and \(d\) from **(b)**(ii) to calculate a value \(f_{1}\) for the focal length of the lens.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 581, 492, 599]]<|/det|>
Give your answer to 3 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 688, 920, 707]]<|/det|>
<form>f_{1} = ................................................................. $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 689, 920, 707]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 918, 90]]<|/det|> The student repeats the procedure in (a) and (b) for an object to screen distance \(D = 100.0 \text{cm}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 535, 121]]<|/det|> The student records the values of \(X,\) \(Y\) and \(d.\) <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 134, 917, 160]]<|/det|> \[X = \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \quad 18.1 \text{cm} \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \text{DO}\] \[Y = \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \quad 81.8 \text{cm} \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \text{DO}\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 206, 917, 224]]<|/det|>
d = \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \quad 63.7 \text{cm} \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \text{DO} <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 240, 840, 257]]<|/det|> Calculate a second value \(f_{2}\) for the focal length of the lens using the equation in (c). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 351, 917, 369]]<|/det|> f_{2} = \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \quad \text{cm} \quad [1] \quad \text{DO} <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 383, 146, 401]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 383, 920, 415]]<|/det|> Two quantities can be considered to be equal within the limits of experimental accuracy if their values are within \(10\%\) of each other. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 429, 812, 446]]<|/det|> State whether your values of \(f_{1}\) and \(f_{2}\) from (c) and (d) can be considered equal. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 460, 502, 477]]<|/det|> Support your statement with a calculation. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 630, 917, 646]]<|/det|> 
statement ....................................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 675, 910, 693]]<|/det|>
[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 144, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 180, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 72, 917, 106]]<|/det|>
State one technique to use when doing this type of experiment to ensure that the image on the screen is focused as clearly as possible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 180, 918, 199]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 211, 181, 230]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 211, 626, 230]]<|/det|>
This experiment is usually done in a darkened room.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 242, 745, 260]]<|/det|>
Explain how this makes it easier to see when the image is in focus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[834, 333, 920, 352]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 772, 90]]<|/det|>
Hot water is poured into a glass beaker and allowed to cool down for 5 minutes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 104, 917, 136]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate whether the rate of cooling of the hot water depends upon the initial temperature of the hot water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 151, 687, 167]]<|/det|>
The rate of cooling of the water can be calculated using the equation:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[322, 172, 673, 202]]<|/det|>
\[\text{rate of cooling} = \frac{\text{decrease in temperature}}{\text{time taken}}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 212, 304, 228]]<|/det|>
You are provided with:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 243, 340, 258]]<|/det|>
· a supply of cold water

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 260, 280, 273]]<|/det|>
· an electric kettle

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 275, 351, 289]]<|/det|>
· a \(250cm^3\) glass beaker

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 291, 335, 305]]<|/det|>
· a measuring cylinder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 320, 565, 336]]<|/det|>
You may use any other common laboratory apparatus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 351, 293, 366]]<|/det|>
In your plan, include:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 382, 393, 396]]<|/det|>
· any other apparatus needed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 397, 917, 427]]<|/det|>
· a brief description of the method, including what you will measure and how you will make sure your measurements are accurate

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 429, 393, 443]]<|/det|>
· the variables you will control

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 445, 917, 475]]<|/det|>
· a results table to record your measurements (you are not required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 476, 615, 490]]<|/det|>
· how you will process your results to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 506, 418, 521]]<|/det|>
You may include a labelled diagram.
